summary: A quick-key tool for controlling various ENB effects and settings.
descriptionHtml:
[color=#FF8000][b]DISCLAIMER[/b][/color]

This tool works by making PERMANENT changes to your ENB configuration files, and as such, it can haphazardly mess them up in the unfortunate event that something goes south. Although I have tested the tool (not really), please take no chances and back-up your files before using it. In no case I will be held responsible if the tool makes a mess of the setup you\'ve spent last half a year polishing.

[color=#FF8000][b]SO... WHAT IS THIS THING?[/b][/color]

ENBmote is tiny tool to enable and disable selected ENB effects and change certain settings in-game, in realtime.

Currently implemented features:

Enable and disable Matso\'s Depth of Field effect*1
Enable and disable Matso\'s Grain effect
Enable and disable Matso\'s Chromatic Aberration
Enable and disable Matso\'s Sharpening
Enable and disable HD6\'s Vignette (ie. black stripes)
Enable and disable Matso\'s Panoramic Stripes (Vignette)
Enable and disable effect.fx*2
Enable and disable Original Game Colour Correction
Switch between HD6\'s Crisp Bloom and Screen Bloom
Switch between Post-Process 2 and 5

*1 Only Matso\'s ENB prepass modifications 4.0.0 are supported for now.
*2 Doesn\'t seem to work properly right now at least on my system.

Especially the last three settings are geared more towards the hardcore ENB crowd, as the typical ENB setups available for download are not configured to look correct with alternate settings.

More features can be implemented based on user feedback, so don\'t hesitate to give suggestions.

[color=#FF8000][b]GREAT, HOW DO I INSTALL?[/b][/color]

First, copy the included files into the Skyrim program folder - the same folder where the game executables are located.

To configure quick-keys, run ENBmote Configurator. You don\'t have to assign a key to every setting - you can simply use the ones you want to.

Notice that the configurator lets you set a same key for two or more settings - so you can control various settings with just one quick-key.

After you\'ve set the keys to your liking, click Save to save the settings and exit the configurator.

To use the quick-keys, simply run ENBmote (enbmote.exe) before you launch Skyrim, and when in-game, press the desired quick-key. If your ENB setup is configured to refresh settings with BACKSPACE (it is by default), the new settings take place automatically.

When in-game, you can always switch to desktop and re-run the configurator to change the quick-keys - no need to shut down ENBmote beforehand. You can also view the quick-keys by clicking the tray icon and selecting View Quick-keys.

After you\'ve had your daily dosage of Skyrim, exit the tool via its tray menu. Note that if you\'ve disabled effect.txt, the tool will enable it upon exit.

[color=#FF8000][b]UM, ANY KNOWN ISSUES?[/b][/color]

As with all alpha versions, there are indeed certain issues:

Upon applying a quick-key, there\'s a slight delay especially on slower systems. This is unfortunate but also unavoidable in order to ensure proper communication with ENB.

When using Matso\'s enbeffectprepass.fx, not all effect combinations are automatically valid without setting up the file properly. Before using quick-keys, make sure your desired effect combination works.

The quick-key for toggling effect.fx doesn\'t seem to work without switching to desktop at least on my system.

And finally, I\'m not a coder by any stretch, so ALWAYS remember to take backup copies of your files.

[color=#FF8000][b]WELL, HOW DO I UNINSTALL?[/b][/color]

Simply delete the following files from the Skyrim program folder:

ENBmote.exe
enbmote.ini
enbmote.png
ENBmote Configurator.exe

If there\'s a demand, future versions might include a dedicated installer.
author: mindflux
